column1: Databases are structured systems designed to store, manage, and retrieve data efficiently. They are fundamental in applications ranging from small data operations to large-scale processing. Here is an outline of their main features:
• Relational databases use structured tables with predefined schemas for precise data management.
• NoSQL databases use flexible data models such as documents, graphs, columnar, or key-value pairs to accommodate various data types and structures.
• Relational Databases: Implement ACID principles (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) to ensure reliable transactions.
• NoSQL Databases: Follow BASE principles (Basically Available, Soft state, Eventually consistent) to support scalability and availability.
• Provides mechanisms like authentication, authorization, and encryption to safeguard data integrity and confidentiality.
• Allows multiple users to access and manipulate data concurrently without compromising data consistency.
• Relational Databases: Scale vertically by increasing hardware resources like memory and CPU.
• NoSQL Databases: Offer horizontal scaling by adding more machines to handle large amounts of data.
• Features for regular backups and recovery options help in protecting data against loss or corruption.
